paragraphs.text: It was probably only a matter of time before ‘platform capitalism’ caught up with the film industry too and started turning Indie Directors into Uber-like ‘film partners’.

paragraphs.text: Netflix and Amazon will certainly turn into a studio system of their own, it’s human nature. OTOH, there is a future where we just have abundant content, because it’s so much easier and cheaper than it used to be. If robots do all the work, there is the potential for great creativity, though I doubt the human race can see it through to that good endpoint.

paragraphs.name: 7c1b
paragraphs.text: Fennessey, this is fantastic work. I hope you continue to take periodic breaks from your editorial work and keep bringing deep dives into worlds that most of us don’t have access to. My work is tangentially related to the subject here so I may have more interest than some; but this article is fascinating and juxtaposes the hard choices that stakeholders at each end will have to make in the near and long term.

paragraphs.name: 77bb
paragraphs.text: This is for me the main advantage Netflix still hold over Amazon. If you do a lot of traveling or live outside the US Amazon can be really frustrating, though at the end of the day both are producing great content and I’m grateful for that.

I can personally attest to having friends tell me of obscure movies I’d never heard of that had become a popular Netflix watch. Also, a lot of would be great indie-filmmakers have taken their talents to TV and that’s also I think smart. TV…

We have an 18-plex and it’s full of children’s films or blockbuster garbage 10 months out of the year…

paragraphs.text: Parker’s Screening Room idea is laughably bad. paragraphs.name: 10ec
paragraphs.text: Warner Independent, Paramount Vantage all went into the dust years ago. But hard to tell this story without figuring out how a24 fits into the equation. There’s unexpected juice in the theatrical market for distributors willing to nurture it. And that can be anyone from Amazon on down.

paragraphs.text: Being an old veteran of the film industry which I equally love and hate, I have been predicting the demise of the industry for a long time. But I think my observation is too harsh. Films are not going away. They are a classic part of our artistic culture over the past 100 years. But the film watching experience is definitely going to change. The era…

e00254ba607f.title: Being an old veteran of the film industry which I equally love and hate, I have been predicting the…

paragraphs.name: aef4
paragraphs.text: In recent years, many of the indie-boutique shingles that the major studios once supported — Paramount Vantage, Warner Independent Pictures — have closed up shop. They’ve become victims of an increasingly corporatized, IP-centric major studio strategy. Those that remain, including Fox Searchlight, Miramax, and Focus Features, have been weakened. These satellite operations working inside corporations supported independent filmmakers and smaller projects, in an effort to serve arthouse audiences, court award season prestige, and provide the corporations a bit of soul. The continued dissolution of these outlets has created an open lane. In their place, a new breed of independent-minded curators — based largely in Silicon Valley and Seattle — has risen. The tension between them starts in theaters and ends at home.

paragraphs.name: 631d
paragraphs.text: “There’s no physical supply chain,” Sarandos told Deadline. “So the idea that you could do something on a global platform was impossible then and more than possible right now — and the norm. Netflix now, we’re in every country in the world except for Syria, North Korea and China. When we launch our movies and TV shows, we launch them everywhere at the same second. When we buy a movie at Sundance, it’s available to the whole world.”
